I picked up Hello Kitty Island Adventure hoping it would be Animal Crossing for PC. It‚Äôs not, but it‚Äôs still fun. There‚Äôs no question that it has some similarities to Animal Crossing, but it just falls short in a number of ways. Most aspects just feel like they‚Äôre missing a little something when compared against Animal Crossing. That‚Äôs not at all to say it‚Äôs a bad game. I still very much enjoy playing it on my Steam Deck.

Like Animal Crossing, you‚Äôre pretty free to go at your own pace, fishing, bug hunting, decorating, and chatting with villagers, although none of these aspects feel as polished or satisfying as Animal Crossing. However, this game is much more story and quest heavy than Animal Crossing. I wouldn‚Äôt call the quests amazing by any means, but they are engaging enough that I would say I spend most of my time doing the quests. The map is also a lot larger and more varied than Animal Crossing, which is cool, but it doesn‚Äôt seem to change at all as seasons pass, which feels like a downgrade. The game does use the real life date for certain things, as Animal Crossing did, but the in game time is not tied to real time. I do miss having the in game world mirror reality, but there is something to be said for not having to wait until a certain real life time for in game events. While you cannot decorate the island at all, there are dozens of cabins that you can unlock and decorate to attract additional villagers. It‚Äôs a neat mechanic, but it does bring me into one of my biggest issues with the game.

One of the biggest issues I have with the game is a lack of currency. Everything is traded. For example, you might go to the store and see a furniture piece needs 10 seashells and 5 pumpkins to trade for it. I much prefer just having 1 universal currency and allowing me to buy and sell as I wish. This makes it sort of annoying to collect clothing and furniture. There‚Äôs not a shortage of materials around to collect, I just find it annoying that I can‚Äôt just know that I have money and go spending. It also makes fishing and bug hunting feel sort of useless since they can‚Äôt be sold and they are less fun to do than in Animal Crossing. Fish can be traded in for a specific furniture set and there is a bug museum, but its sort of annoying to donate to.

The game also has a large focus on gift giving. Ever real life day you can give 3 gifts to each villager to raise their friendship level. It does feel a little repetitive and grindy at times, but it is pretty easy to level up friendship, so I can‚Äôt complain too much. Also I did enjoy trying different recipes at the various cooking stations to see what I could make and who would like it. I do think some of the invalid combinations felt like they really should have made something unique, but you never waste materials as you always at least get a generic item.

In terms of performance, the game runs pretty well. I think I just left the default settings on and I get a mostly stable 60FPS on my Steam Deck. Many areas can hold the full 90, but there were enough dips that I just set it to 60. Even at 60 there are dips, but much fewer.

Overall, if you want Animal Crossing for PC, that is not what this is, but if you want a nice cosy game that runs well on Steam Deck, this is a solid purchase. I‚Äôm a little over 21 hours in and while I got the achievement for unlocking all the areas, I still feel like playing more and still have quests in my quest log.

This game is definitely brutal though with its events and other time-based things. If you stop playing for a couple weeks and miss an event, well now you have to wait a full year to get the items from that event. There are technically ways around this, though, but they mostly involve playing with other people enough times to unlock the ability to have someone else give you the event items, and that takes a shocking amount of time and also not everyone wants to do multiplayer, I'm sure.

Regardless, this game is awesome, I've had so much fun with it, and also this is my first introduction to anything Sanrio-related. I had no idea who any of these characters were before this (except Hello Kitty ofc) and that is definitely fine. It's not a requirement to understand anyone, they will give you a brief introduction, and at this point it feels like I'm very familiar with everyone involved. This game is NOT childish, and frankly not even for children lol. I've been doing literal research for this game like how to crossbreed flowers and I've kept several notepads for collections I've been working towards. I love the feel of the game and it also gets updates fairly regularly!

Also as a side note, the DLC is also worth it, I'd say. It's expensive, sure, but it was a good amount of content, plus a new character and a new world, that both stick around forever. I still only have about half of the items in the DLC, but as for the actual story of it, it took at least 30 hours, and I enjoy all the new stuff that was added. Overall 10/10 would wait a year to unlock a baby named after a beverage again.

Has a similar vibe to Animal Crossing but plays very different. You kind of know what you're getting into: It's going to be a family friendly, safe, cozy game. It's not especially deep, but it's also not that shallow to the point only a child could enjoy it. It hits that happy middle ground of being just engaging enough

The first thing to get over is the games 'time'. There's in-game time and real world time. In-game time has day-night cycles over 4 periods (morning, day, evening, night) that all last 60 minutes. Creatures around the island will appear/disappear at certain periods. Real world time happens every 24 hours based on the location of Sunblink (the devs) studio. Every 24 hours a new 'day' starts. Island resources are finite and reset at the start of each real world day, and seasonal events are also tied to this

There's an overall 'plot' that keeps things progressing. It's not interesting in the slightest, but it's there. I found the dialogue enjoyable enough that I wasn't skipping it. You'll also get prompted for dialogue responses every now and then, however the response you pick doesn't matter. It's a little lame though it does make sense. The devs also make references to memes and movies in a subtle enough way that it got a smile out of me. I was not expecting an American Psycho reference when it popped up

The game has 13 main Friends that you start off with, with 6 additional ones unlocked later as you progress. The characters have defined personalities, hobbies, and interests. It makes them stand out against each other and you can find a favourite (mines Big Challenges). That said, they can at times feel like different shades of the same personality

General gameplay is what you might expect. It's talking to characters, collecting materials, crafting things, decorating etc. There's daily and weekly quests to give you a reason to log in every day. There's also seasonal events constantly happening. It's all pretty fun for the most part

My only major gripe with the game is that while the controls are fine overall, there are times where it can be a little clunky. For example there are Primary and Secondary seasonal Events that occur. Events have booths that you can purchase their seasonal items from located a few steps from each other. On Steamdeck, the interact button is X for one of these booths, and A for the other. Small things like this lead to moments where you'll press a button expecting one thing to happen and something (or nothing) else will. Small things like this can get annoying

Sometimes a game doesn't need to be revolutionary. It doesn't need to break the mold or redefine a genre. Sometimes it just needs to be enjoyable. This game is enjoyable, and that's all it needs to be

Genuinely I wish I could recommend this game, but I cannot.

The parts it does are genuinely really good. It has a decent crafting system, clothing is cute even if the models for clothes are very simple, decorating cabins is okay, and in general the game is cute.

The problem comes from the sheer amount of time gating in this game. Almost every single goal in this game is time gated beyond belief. I have played MMO's with constant FOMO events that respect your time more than this game does. I'll go bit by bit with the most important parts of the game that are time gated.

Resources are spawned every single day, up to three days of stacking. You eventually can become best friends with the main cast of characters and they'll pickup items for you, but at the start of the game you will be absolutely desperate for resources and will need to go manually collect them. There will be days where you will have to throw up your hands and be like "welp, guess I'll just logon tomorrow to be able to craft two iron bars!" 

Friendship leveling is next. You get levels by doing weekly/daily quests and gifting them items of one to three heart levels, with three hearts being best value. You will NEED to level the friendship of other characters because besides making them collect items, they have various abilities that'll make your time in the game better considerably and give you various resources needed to craft items. Later on you can even bring two friends with you, and certain combos can massively boost you. 
The problem though is this is slow, you won't have friend abilities at usable levels or at all for a long while, and best friend status genuinely can take months. There are also certain characters who can take even longer due to their three heart items taking a long time to be able even available to craft. A certain funny bunny being a particular issue, if you know you know.

Quests themselves often have time gates, forcing you to "wait until tomorrow" frequently. This wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't possible to run out of quests to do very often, leading to just multiple days of hopping on and then hopping off. You will eventually reach a state where you literally have no quests to do unless a random time gated friendship quest appears. Quest design in this game is insanely boring though, and eventually I started skipping dialogue. Even worse is that this is acknowledged ingame with your character's useless dialogue choices often having a choice of "okay I guess I'm gathering sticks again", which of course is completely ignored by the cast. There is literally one quest series where you just follow a character around for five minutes with minimal dialogue breaks.

There are constant rotating events, and they are shockingly strict with how much time you have to get enough event currency to obtain items or even just do daily rewards. In a few of the events, missing even one or two days can completely blow your chance of getting every event item. Also before a recent update, older event items had to be obtained via random chance at Tuxedosam and My Melody's shops. That has been fixed though, with event stands allowing you to just get older items easily now.

Finally the bit I hate most, the visitor system. A ton of quests, functions, etc are hidden behind the visitor system. If you are aiming to get the one hidden achievement, you will be waiting a full year as you are stopped by seasonally locked visitors, event item locked visitors, and literal months long waits for a few of the visitors. Visitors come for a "week" long period when their rotation happens. Some visitors appear anytime though. It is not a week however for rotation based visitors, it is five days from Thursday to Monday. You can "max out" their chances of appearing, but honestly it doesn't feel like it. Other people have noticed, but since a certain update visitors seem to have lower chances to appear, so realistically you will see them max twice a week. If you have many visiting at once though their quest to get stars (max five before being allowed to permanently stay) might not even appear due to the dailies having a max quest limit. On top of this sometimes they just won't give quests at all. Visitors will not appear two days in a row, and only leaving if their quest is done to hopefully visit another time in the rotation.
This leads to intense frustration, as some visitors only visit once a real time month as noted before, and those visitors often have some of the meatier content behind them including unlocking other visitors.

I understand the goal of this game is to not rush, but they have done everything in their power to make sure you don't have a choice. "Time travel" (setting your clock forward) breaks large chunks of the game, including events and multiplayer. If you want to experience the game in full, you are forced to endure the constant time gating.

Once I get my final achievement, I'll probably put down the game, as it lost its charm many hours ago and is just exhausting me now. This doesn't feel as fun anymore, it feels like a chores simulator with a Hello Kitty flavoring. 

If you do decide to get it, wait for the base game to be 20 USD (or equivalent in your local currency) or lower, and don't be afraid to quit playing if it starts to burn you out. My silly self is in too deep now.

- originally a mobile game
- made for kids

If you're fine with all these things (like I was) and want to play for cute cozy chill vibes, that's exactly what you'll find. The game is nice, but is a clear case of predatory FOMO design. If you're buying this game, be ready to be mildy annoyed often, or feeling like giving up after realizing you have to wait 365 days just to potentially have access to something again. And if you're getting it for your kid, be ready for 'the DLC talk' or a lot of complaining once they finish the main story.
